title: 2025 Bespoked UK Day 02: Alonukis, BTR, Cotic, Feather, Rasch, Sideways, Stayer, Tailfin, Ted James – John Watson
content:
Bespoked UK has long been on John’s “must-see” list of framebuilder showcases, and this year, he finally got to attend the UK event. Read on for a jam-packed gallery, oozing with fillets, finishes, and more from some of his favorites during day 02 at the 2025 Bespoked UK!

The Radavist thanks Tailfin for supporting our 2025 Bespoked UK coverage and our independent Reportage!

Alonukis Frameworks Sidetracker Mountain Touring Bike for Too Tired

Bespoked UK was all about meeting framebuilders who are new to me, even if they aren’t new to the craft. One of whom was Johannes from Alonukis, who has been building frames for three years total, but two years full-time. The brand name is an anagram of Nikolaus, his middle name. Dubbed the Sidetracker, this 650b touring mountain bike was built for a friend’s brand, Too Tired.

The bike features restomod detailing, with beautiful TIG beads and a two-tone lavender Cerakote finish. What struck me was the Yeti-inspired top tube cable routing, the unique fork with corked ends (for stashing), a stunning head badge, Paul Components parts, and NOS Odyssey Svelte skewers that were mis-assembled from the factory with the incorrect orientation. I loved the turned-down/milled brass bits and black Cerakote chainrings, with the outer acting as a bash guard, which Too Tired engraved.

Spending time poring over bikes with my lens is one of my favorite parts about framebuilder showcases, and each time I thought I was done with the Sidetracker, some new detail would reveal itself. Perhaps this is why it won “Best Gravel Bike” at Bespoked UK.

@AlonukisFrameworks

BTR Fabrications’ Rat Bikes “Dad Rat”

The quintessential pub bike, around-town jammer, basket bike. Rigid mountain bikes make for great all-rounders, and when they’re bomber like this, they encourage curb jibs and singletrack runs along the way. That’s what BTR Fabrications’ new production line, Rat Bikes, displayed with its Dad Rat bike. Paul Burford explained the intent behind the bike to me as I documented its jet-black sleekness on the second morning at Bespoked UK.

These bikes feature a series of folded sheet metal details at the chainstay yoke, dropouts, and brake mounts. Paul has an in-production photo on the BTR Instagram that showcases it wonderfully. The intention here is to make as much of the bike in-house, saving money and fabrication time, to offer these frames as affordably as possible (£650 frame). Paul’s personal bike, pictured here, features a brilliant truss fork and a clean build, featuring Hope Tech parts. We’ve got a deeper, more in-depth look at the Rat Bikes project coming later this year, so expect future updates!

Until then, I just wanted to shout out Paul, who made me feel very welcome in the Bespoked UK family this past weekend.

@BTR_Fabrications

Cotic Bikes FlareMAX 29er Full Suspension

What can I even say about the FlareMAX here that hasn’t already been said multiple times on this very website over the past year and a half? These bikes are legitimately fun, just like this À La Carte paint option Cotic now offers on all its bikes. This one particular paint job has a cheeky backstory.

“The backstory on these particular colors is a nod back to when Cotic first started. The first 100 frames were ordered in grey colour code 817. They were agented by a business that had done pink frames, and the agent just thought it was a mistake. Pink is color code 718. So, the first 100 Cotic Souls were bright Barbie pink,” Cy explained to me. This prompted them to repaint many of them grey, and some orange. That’s why the launch of the new look is grey and pink — a little nod to the start of Cotic.

The grey-pink fade is accentuated by the bright silver Hope Tech and Vivo rear mech, which looks great on the bike if I do say so myself! Thanks for the hangs and the chats, Cy!

@CoticBikes

Feather Cycles Stainless Road

York-based Ricky Feather makes exceptional bikes, fabricated using lugged or fillet brazed construction techniques. While the Feather Cycles booth was loaded to the brim with eye candy, one bike in particular stood out to me with its imperfect perfection paint job and blackened fillet joints. The paint job was inspired by the client’s daughter’s painting and was emulated in the same manner on the front of the frame, covering the top, down, and headtube, along with the fork and stem.

To blacken the brass fillets, Ricky used liver of sulfur after they were filed and sanded to perfection. Stainless steel can be fillet brazed, and this is a perfect way to achieve a raw fillet look without compromising frame integrity when leaving a normal steel frame raw with a clear coat.

The Feather downtube logo is subtle, and the Feather laser-cut dropouts were painted to match the front triangle’s adornment. This feather-light rim brake road bike uses Berd spokes and eeBrakes, offering a classic look without compromising performance. Last year, Ricky announced that he’s only going to make 50 more frames before closing down Feather Cycles, so if you’ve long admired his work, now’s the time to get in the queue…

@FeatherCycles

Rasch Cycles First Frame

For the past year and a half, Kata Rasch has been working with Konstantin Drust in his workshop, learning how to build frames. When she’s not hauling around two full-size dogs in an Omnium Cargo (non-electric, mind you!) through the streets of Berlin, she’s in the shop, mitering and fillet brazing frames. The elegantly sloped top tube allows for standover height, and the tire clearance with an MTB drivetrain allows for 27.5 x 2.3″ tires to clear the perfectly-shaped chainstays. While the bike’s paint covers Kata’s fillet brazing work, she left the stem raw to showcase her talents.

On the last day of the show, she requested photos in a spot she had picked out in the Victoria Baths, with light flooding the beautiful green tile wall from a pre-war skylight. I just wanted to thank not only Hope Tech but also Seido Components for helping Kata present her first bike at Bespoked UK. Getting to hang out with the next generation of framebuilders is always a treat, and Kata’s style and energy were wonderful.

Kata wants to one day open a class for women and other non-male people who would like to learn how to build frames. I asked her for a quote about the project:

“I think working with metal is still very male-dominated and can be a barrier for those who are not cis-male socialized. I currently work in a metal shop at university, teaching students the basics of metalworking. Often, non-male students are nervous about working on the lathes, but after a short while, they usually really enjoy it, and I’m happy to support them. I want to do the same with what I enjoy the most, and that’s framebuilding.

I think an experience like building your own bike can sometimes have a big impact on your life. I also did a course at Drust Cycles once, and that confirmed my decision to apply for a job in the metal workshop. I would be very happy if people would also like to share such an experience and especially the passion for bikes and cycling. But until then, I want to learn more myself.”

@RaschCycles

Sideways Scraps Carbon Scraps Pub Bike

As Viola Townsend rolled her bikes through the Bespoked UK showcase on setup day, I caught up with the first-year SRAM Inclusivity scholarship winner. “The coverage on The Radavist last year sold my first bike,” she exclaimed. While her two “show” bikes looked impeccable, it was the bar bike that stoked me out. Made from scraps of carbon, this bike reimagines carbon fiber sustainability.

While this isn’t something Viola would do for a customer, it made for a perfect pub bike for her to ride around the Northeast of England where her shop is based. The vibrant paint is accentuated by the equally as flash Wizard Works partial frame bag. Plus, I love how this portrait turned out.

Viola, it was a pleasure meeting you. Thank you!

@Sideways.Bike

Stayer Cycles Step-Through Commuter

Sam from Stayer Cycles offers a Framebuilding 101 course in his East London shop. And it was through these one-on-one courses that he had an idea for a trifecta of frame offerings for the future. One of which is his stunning stayTB project, another focuses on modifying or repairing older vintage MTB frames, and the third is practical commuter frames. You’re looking at proof of concept number one for the latter.

“Did you get a knurling machine?” Pi Mason from Clandestine commented as he walked by as I was documenting the bike. “Sure did!” Laughed Sam, which sent me scanning the bike for all possible photo opportunities of knurled steel on this stunning bike, on top of all the other small stories that can be told of its form and function. The rear D-hoop barwork is for his daughter to ride on the rear of the bike, while holding onto Sam’s shoulders. They’re mounted to track ends from an old Bespoked bike that Sam had made.

Hulsroy made the chainstay yoke, and perhaps the most interesting “show bike” feature is the T47 square taper bottom bracket, made by Paul from Rideworks. Annnnnnnnd I kinda really want one!

Right before Sam boarded the bike for its first pedal, I hollered at him, “Hold up! Did you intentionally match your Nikes to that logo?!” We both had a laugh. Well done, sir.

@StayerCycles

Alex’s Fairlight Holt with Tailfin R&D Bags

Fresh off the Silk Road Mountain Race, Tailfin brought its R&D athlete Alex McCormack’s Fairlight Holt hardtail. As we wrestled it out of the Tailfin booth, dust and dirt fell all over the bike stand. Patina procured through pain and perseverance at its finest, folks. Alex’s minimal kit features a prototype rear bag, a Downtube Pack, and a long Top Tube Bag.

The off-white custom framebag is a hint at what the brand is currently developing. More on that later…

@TailfinCycling

Ted James Design Prototype Full Suspension

“I was up until 4 AM assembling the bike,” Ted James sleepily muttered to me as we rolled his prototype full-suspension out the doors from Bespoked UK. “It’s barely put together.” Already, my mind was racing, and a bead of sweat formed under my cap as the sun poked through a cloudy Manchester sky. Wow. I’ve known “Super” Ted since 2008, during the peak of fixed-gear madness. Ted and I have ridden in New York and Japan. The bike control this man possesses is outstanding. He’s the kinda guy that always looks like a bike has sprung from him. He never rides a bike; the bike is an extension of him.

While the project has been in Ted’s mind for some time, he finally put in a heroic effort to “complete” it in time for the show. He rambled off all the details as I raced around the bike trying to document it, meanwhile his two sons, Elwood and Rider, had a client’s mini velo bike out riding hot laps in the car park, yelling over to us “Dad! This bike jumps really well!” Ted looked at me and smiled with a look of beautiful adoration for his two kids.

This bike is insane, and yet it’s not a tank. Lifting it into position, I could feel a few loose linkage components, but the intent was there and it was surprisingly light. Ted mentioned the bike’s modularity, “It has a 27.5-inch rear wheel now and a 29er front, but I want to put a 26-inch wheel in the rear and a 27.5-inch wheel in the front.” Ted designed the bike to be built with 140 mm or 160 mm of rear travel, and the model can be made for 120 through 180 mm front travel. He’s also offering a titanium version which will be considerably lighter. Oh and those 10 mm thick rocker panels will be milled down… eventually.

What was by far most surprising for me was the inclusion of a Pinion gearbox, which requires an idler pulley, further complicating the suspension design. AND what is fucking mind-blowing about all this is that Ted simply sketches out by hand, without using CAD at all. It’s all in the man’s head. “I had to flip the shock around because the piggyback hit the downtube.”

I could write 1000 words alone on everything we discussed, but we’ve got two more bikes to look at…

Ted James Design Mini Velo

“The client is in his sixties. He was one of the early adopters of mountain bikes in the UK and just wants something to ride around in the city on.” Again, this is mad genius material from Ted James. The fully stainless steel mini velo features a Cannondale Delta V-inspired design, with a longer rear-center to keep the bike stable in cornering. Ted’s stainless mixture consists of Reynolds 953, 931, and 921. For a seatstay break, instead of using a coupler, Ted drilled and threaded the dropout, attaching the seat stay to it with a button-head bolt. (Of course, the one photo I missed focusing on this weekend was of that detail.) An eccentric bottom bracket maintains belt tension, and the custom stainless steel rack attaches to the Pacenti fork crown.

This bike won “Best City/Utility” at the 2025 Bespoked UK showcase.

Elwood’s Ted James Design Titanium BMX

“I put the logo on the underside of the downtube because I figured it’d be best for photos when I’m doing tabletops,” Elwood remarked to me as I requested he pause for a second with the bike for a few photos. He’d been zipping around the car park on this titanium BMX bike, which he’s already outgrowing. “Take another run, please!” I shouted as I dialed in my shutter speed for a panning shot of him feeble grinding a Corten steel bench. “As soon as we rolled up, the security guard saw us and shook their head,” Ted laughed. Metal on metal clanged, my shutter trickled, and I had a quick chimp afterward. “Got it. Wanna see?” I showed the camera to Elwood. “Oh, that’s sick,” he replied.

After Ted and I recalled our last encounter, our hopes and aspirations, and the trials and tribulations of being small-time players in this big industry, we ended our time with a quick back-and-forth. One of his kids yelled, “Dad, you need to charge more money for your frames!”

“Fuck man, we’re adults now,” I jokingly commented to Ted. He replied, “No, we’re just kids still…”

Ted, this was one of my favorite photoshoots from the weekend. May you and your sons keep shredding, and I cannot wait to see V2 of your full-suspension!

xo

 

 

Well, which build is your favorite? Let us know in the comments!
